trans-unit.source: How to create a hybrid collection for Azure RemoteApp
trans-unit.target: How to create a hybrid collection for Azure RemoteApp

trans-unit.source: Learn how to create a deployment of RemoteApp that connects to your internal network.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to create a deployment of RemoteApp that connects to your internal network.

trans-unit.source: How to create a hybrid collection for Azure RemoteApp
trans-unit.target: How to create a hybrid collection for Azure RemoteApp

trans-unit.source: There are two kinds of RemoteApp collections:
trans-unit.target: There are two kinds of RemoteApp collections:

trans-unit.source: Cloud: resides completely in Azure.
trans-unit.target: Cloud: resides completely in Azure.

trans-unit.source: You can choose to save all data in the cloud (so a cloud-only collection) or to connect your collection to a VNET and save data there.
trans-unit.target: You can choose to save all data in the cloud (so a cloud-only collection) or to connect your collection to a VNET and save data there.

trans-unit.source: Hybrid: includes a virtual network for on-premises access - this requires the use of Azure AD and an on-premises Active Directory environment.
trans-unit.target: Hybrid: includes a virtual network for on-premises access - this requires the use of Azure AD and an on-premises Active Directory environment.

trans-unit.source: Note *This topic is in the middle of being reworked.
trans-unit.target: Note *This topic is in the middle of being reworked.

trans-unit.source: I'm working on a couple of new articles that will make it much easier to figure out your authentication and collection options.
trans-unit.target: I'm working on a couple of new articles that will make it much easier to figure out your authentication and collection options.

trans-unit.source: So, if you're confused, please know that I know and am working as quickly as I can to get better info to you.
trans-unit.target: So, if you're confused, please know that I know and am working as quickly as I can to get better info to you.

trans-unit.source: Thanks.*
trans-unit.target: Thanks.*

trans-unit.source: This tutorial walks you through the process of creating a hybrid collection.
trans-unit.target: This tutorial walks you through the process of creating a hybrid collection.

trans-unit.source: There are eight steps:
trans-unit.target: There are eight steps:

trans-unit.source: Decide what <link><linkText>image</linkText><title></title></link> to use for your collection.
trans-unit.target: Decide what <link><linkText>image</linkText><title></title></link> to use for your collection.

trans-unit.source: You can create a custom image or use one of the Microsoft images included with your subscription.
trans-unit.target: You can create a custom image or use one of the Microsoft images included with your subscription.

trans-unit.source: Set up your virtual network.
trans-unit.target: Set up your virtual network.

trans-unit.source: Create a RemoteApp collection.
trans-unit.target: Create a RemoteApp collection.

trans-unit.source: Join your collection to your local domain.
trans-unit.target: Join your collection to your local domain.

trans-unit.source: Add a template image to your collection.
trans-unit.target: Add a template image to your collection.

trans-unit.source: Configure directory synchronization.
trans-unit.target: Configure directory synchronization.

trans-unit.source: RemoteApp requires that you integrate with Azure Active Directory by either 1) configuring Azure Active Directory Sync with the Password Sync option, or 2) configuring Azure Active Directory Sync without the Password Sync option but using a domain that is federated to AD FS.
trans-unit.target: RemoteApp requires that you integrate with Azure Active Directory by either 1) configuring Azure Active Directory Sync with the Password Sync option, or 2) configuring Azure Active Directory Sync without the Password Sync option but using a domain that is federated to AD FS.

trans-unit.source: Check out the <link><linkText>configuration info for Active Directory with RemoteApp</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: Check out the <link><linkText>configuration info for Active Directory with RemoteApp</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Publish RemoteApp apps.
trans-unit.target: Publish RemoteApp apps.

trans-unit.source: Configure user access.
trans-unit.target: Configure user access.

trans-unit.source: Before you begin
trans-unit.target: Before you begin

trans-unit.source: You need to do the following before creating the collection:
trans-unit.target: You need to do the following before creating the collection:

trans-unit.source: <link><linkText>Sign up</linkText><title></title></link> for RemoteApp.
trans-unit.target: <link><linkText>Sign up</linkText><title></title></link> for RemoteApp.

trans-unit.source: Create a user account in Active Directory to use as the RemoteApp service account.
trans-unit.target: Create a user account in Active Directory to use as the RemoteApp service account.

trans-unit.source: Restrict the permissions for this account so that it can only join machines to the domain.
trans-unit.target: Restrict the permissions for this account so that it can only join machines to the domain.

trans-unit.source: Gather information about your on-premises network: IP address information and VPN device details.
trans-unit.target: Gather information about your on-premises network: IP address information and VPN device details.

trans-unit.source: Install the <link><linkText>Azure PowerShell</linkText><title></title></link> module.
trans-unit.target: Install the <link><linkText>Azure PowerShell</linkText><title></title></link> module.

trans-unit.source: Gather information about the users that you want to grant access to.
trans-unit.target: Gather information about the users that you want to grant access to.

trans-unit.source: You will need the Azure Active Directory user principal name (for example, name@contoso.com) for each user.
trans-unit.target: You will need the Azure Active Directory user principal name (for example, name@contoso.com) for each user.

trans-unit.source: Make sure that the UPN matches between Azure AD and Active Directory.
trans-unit.target: Make sure that the UPN matches between Azure AD and Active Directory.

trans-unit.source: Choose your template image.
trans-unit.target: Choose your template image.

trans-unit.source: A RemoteApp template image contains the apps and programs that you want to publish for your users.
trans-unit.target: A RemoteApp template image contains the apps and programs that you want to publish for your users.

trans-unit.source: See <link><linkText>RemoteApp image options</linkText><title></title></link> for more information.
trans-unit.target: See <link><linkText>RemoteApp image options</linkText><title></title></link> for more information.

trans-unit.source: Want to use the Office 365 ProPlus image?
trans-unit.target: Want to use the Office 365 ProPlus image?

trans-unit.source: Check out info <link><linkText>here</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: Check out info <link><linkText>here</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: <link><linkText>Configure Active Directory for RemoteApp</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: <link><linkText>Configure Active Directory for RemoteApp</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Step 1: Set up your virtual network
trans-unit.target: Step 1: Set up your virtual network

trans-unit.source: You can deploy a hybrid RemoteApp collection that uses an existing Azure virtual network, or you can create a new virtual network.
trans-unit.target: You can deploy a hybrid RemoteApp collection that uses an existing Azure virtual network, or you can create a new virtual network.

trans-unit.source: A virtual network lets your users access data on your local network through RemoteApp remote resources.
trans-unit.target: A virtual network lets your users access data on your local network through RemoteApp remote resources.

trans-unit.source: Using an Azure virtual network gives your collection direct network access to other Azure services and virtual machines deployed to that virtual network.
trans-unit.target: Using an Azure virtual network gives your collection direct network access to other Azure services and virtual machines deployed to that virtual network.

trans-unit.source: Make sure you review the <link><linkText>VNET size</linkText><title></title></link> information before you create your VNET.
trans-unit.target: Make sure you review the <link><linkText>VNET size</linkText><title></title></link> information before you create your VNET.

trans-unit.source: Create an Azure VNET and join it to your Active Directory deployment
trans-unit.target: Create an Azure VNET and join it to your Active Directory deployment

trans-unit.source: Start by creating a <link><linkText>virtual network</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: Start by creating a <link><linkText>virtual network</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: This is done on the Network tab in the Azure Management portal.
trans-unit.target: This is done on the Network tab in the Azure Management portal.

trans-unit.source: You need to connect your virtual network to the Active Directory deployment that is synchronized to your Azure Active Directory tenant.
trans-unit.target: You need to connect your virtual network to the Active Directory deployment that is synchronized to your Azure Active Directory tenant.

trans-unit.source: See <link><linkText>About Virtual Network Settings in the Management Portal</linkText><title></title></link> for more information.
trans-unit.target: See <link><linkText>About Virtual Network Settings in the Management Portal</linkText><title></title></link> for more information.

trans-unit.source: Make sure your virtual network is ready for RemoteApp
trans-unit.target: Make sure your virtual network is ready for RemoteApp

trans-unit.source: Before you create your RemoteApp collection, let's make sure that your new virtual network is ready.
trans-unit.target: Before you create your RemoteApp collection, let's make sure that your new virtual network is ready.

trans-unit.source: You can validate this by doing the following:
trans-unit.target: You can validate this by doing the following:

trans-unit.source: Create an Azure virtual machine inside the subnet of the virtual network you just created for RemoteApp.
trans-unit.target: Create an Azure virtual machine inside the subnet of the virtual network you just created for RemoteApp.

trans-unit.source: Use Remote Desktop to connect to the virtual machine.
trans-unit.target: Use Remote Desktop to connect to the virtual machine.

trans-unit.source: (Click Connect.)
trans-unit.target: (Click Connect.)

trans-unit.source: Join it to the same Active Directory deployment that you want to use for RemoteApp.
trans-unit.target: Join it to the same Active Directory deployment that you want to use for RemoteApp.

trans-unit.source: Did that work?
trans-unit.target: Did that work?

trans-unit.source: Your virtual network and subnet are ready for RemoteApp!
trans-unit.target: Your virtual network and subnet are ready for RemoteApp!

trans-unit.source: You can find more information about creating Azure virtual machines and connecting to them with Remote Desktop <link><linkText>here</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: You can find more information about creating Azure virtual machines and connecting to them with Remote Desktop <link><linkText>here</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Step 2: Create a RemoteApp collection
trans-unit.target: Step 2: Create a RemoteApp collection

trans-unit.source: In the <link><linkText>Azure portal</linkText><title></title></link>, go to the RemoteApp page.
trans-unit.target: In the <link><linkText>Azure portal</linkText><title></title></link>, go to the RemoteApp page.

trans-unit.source: Click New > Create with VNET.
trans-unit.target: Click New > Create with VNET.

trans-unit.source: Enter a name for your collection.
trans-unit.target: Enter a name for your collection.

trans-unit.source: Choose the plan that you want to use - standard or basic.
trans-unit.target: Choose the plan that you want to use - standard or basic.

trans-unit.source: Choose your VNET from the drop down list and then your subnet.
trans-unit.target: Choose your VNET from the drop down list and then your subnet.

trans-unit.source: Choose to join it to your domain.
trans-unit.target: Choose to join it to your domain.

trans-unit.source: Click Create RemoteApp collection.
trans-unit.target: Click Create RemoteApp collection.

trans-unit.source: After your RemoteApp collection has been created, double-click the name of the collection.
trans-unit.target: After your RemoteApp collection has been created, double-click the name of the collection.

trans-unit.source: That will bring up the Quick Start page - this is where you finish configuring the collection.
trans-unit.target: That will bring up the Quick Start page - this is where you finish configuring the collection.

trans-unit.source: Step 3: Link your collection to the local domain
trans-unit.target: Step 3: Link your collection to the local domain

trans-unit.source: On the Quick Start page, click join a local domain.
trans-unit.target: On the Quick Start page, click join a local domain.

trans-unit.source: Add the RemoteApp service account to your local Active Directory domain.
trans-unit.target: Add the RemoteApp service account to your local Active Directory domain.

trans-unit.source: You will need the domain name, organizational unit, service account user name and password.
trans-unit.target: You will need the domain name, organizational unit, service account user name and password.

trans-unit.source: This is the information you gathered if you followed the steps in <link><linkText>Configure Active Directory for Azure RemoteApp</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: This is the information you gathered if you followed the steps in <link><linkText>Configure Active Directory for Azure RemoteApp</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Step 4: Link to a RemoteApp image
trans-unit.target: Step 4: Link to a RemoteApp image

trans-unit.source: A RemoteApp template image contains the programs that you want to share with users.
trans-unit.target: A RemoteApp template image contains the programs that you want to share with users.

trans-unit.source: You can either create a new <link><linkText>template image</linkText><title></title></link> or link to an existing image (one already imported or uploaded to Azure RemoteApp).
trans-unit.target: You can either create a new <link><linkText>template image</linkText><title></title></link> or link to an existing image (one already imported or uploaded to Azure RemoteApp).

trans-unit.source: You can also link to one of the RemoteApp <link><linkText>template images</linkText><title></title></link> that contain Office 365 or Office 2013 (for trial use) programs.
trans-unit.target: You can also link to one of the RemoteApp <link><linkText>template images</linkText><title></title></link> that contain Office 365 or Office 2013 (for trial use) programs.

trans-unit.source: If you are uploading the new image, you need to enter the name and choose the location for the image.
trans-unit.target: If you are uploading the new image, you need to enter the name and choose the location for the image.

trans-unit.source: On the next page of the wizard, you'll see a set of PowerShell cmdlets - copy and run these cmdlets from an elevated Windows PowerShell prompt to upload the specified image.
trans-unit.target: On the next page of the wizard, you'll see a set of PowerShell cmdlets - copy and run these cmdlets from an elevated Windows PowerShell prompt to upload the specified image.

trans-unit.source: If you are linking to an existing template image, simply specify the image name, location, and associated Azure subscription.
trans-unit.target: If you are linking to an existing template image, simply specify the image name, location, and associated Azure subscription.

trans-unit.source: Step 5: Configure Active Directory directory synchronization
trans-unit.target: Step 5: Configure Active Directory directory synchronization

trans-unit.source: RemoteApp requires that you integrate with Azure Active Directory by either 1) configuring Azure Active Directory Sync with the Password Sync option, or 2) configuring Azure Active Directory Sync without the Password Sync option but using a domain that is federated to AD FS.
trans-unit.target: RemoteApp requires that you integrate with Azure Active Directory by either 1) configuring Azure Active Directory Sync with the Password Sync option, or 2) configuring Azure Active Directory Sync without the Password Sync option but using a domain that is federated to AD FS.

trans-unit.source: Check out <link><linkText>AD Connect</linkText><title></title></link> - this article helps you set up directory integration in 4 steps.
trans-unit.target: Check out <link><linkText>AD Connect</linkText><title></title></link> - this article helps you set up directory integration in 4 steps.

trans-unit.source: See <link><linkText>Directory synchronization roadmap</linkText><title></title></link> for planning information and detailed steps.
trans-unit.target: See <link><linkText>Directory synchronization roadmap</linkText><title></title></link> for planning information and detailed steps.

trans-unit.source: Step 6: Publish RemoteApp apps
trans-unit.target: Step 6: Publish RemoteApp apps

trans-unit.source: A RemoteApp app is the app or program that you provide to your users.
trans-unit.target: A RemoteApp app is the app or program that you provide to your users.

trans-unit.source: It is located in the template image you uploaded for the collection.
trans-unit.target: It is located in the template image you uploaded for the collection.

trans-unit.source: When a user accesses an app, it appears to run in their local environment, but it is really running in Azure.
trans-unit.target: When a user accesses an app, it appears to run in their local environment, but it is really running in Azure.

trans-unit.source: Before your users can access RemoteApp apps, you need to publish them to the end-user feed – a list of available apps that your users access through the Remote Desktop client.
trans-unit.target: Before your users can access RemoteApp apps, you need to publish them to the end-user feed – a list of available apps that your users access through the Remote Desktop client.

trans-unit.source: You can publish multiple apps to your RemoteApp collection.
trans-unit.target: You can publish multiple apps to your RemoteApp collection.

trans-unit.source: From the RemoteApp publishing page, click Publish to add an app.
trans-unit.target: From the RemoteApp publishing page, click Publish to add an app.

trans-unit.source: You can either publish from the Start menu of the template image or by specifying the path on the template image for the app.
trans-unit.target: You can either publish from the Start menu of the template image or by specifying the path on the template image for the app.

trans-unit.source: If you choose to add from the Start menu, choose the program to app.
trans-unit.target: If you choose to add from the Start menu, choose the program to app.

trans-unit.source: If you choose to provide the path to the app, provide a name for the app and the path to where it is installed on the template image.
trans-unit.target: If you choose to provide the path to the app, provide a name for the app and the path to where it is installed on the template image.

trans-unit.source: Step 7: Configure user access
trans-unit.target: Step 7: Configure user access

trans-unit.source: Now that you have created your RemoteApp collection, you need to add the users that you want to be able to use your remote resources.
trans-unit.target: Now that you have created your RemoteApp collection, you need to add the users that you want to be able to use your remote resources.

trans-unit.source: The users that you provide access to need to exist in the Active Directory tenant associated with the subscription you used to create this RemoteApp collection.
trans-unit.target: The users that you provide access to need to exist in the Active Directory tenant associated with the subscription you used to create this RemoteApp collection.

trans-unit.source: From the Quick Start page, click Configure user access.
trans-unit.target: From the Quick Start page, click Configure user access.

trans-unit.source: Enter the work account (from Active Directory) or Microsoft account that you want to grant access for.
trans-unit.target: Enter the work account (from Active Directory) or Microsoft account that you want to grant access for.

trans-unit.source: Notes:
trans-unit.target: Notes:

trans-unit.source: Make sure that you use the “user@domain.com” format.
trans-unit.target: Make sure that you use the “user@domain.com” format.

trans-unit.source: If you are using Office 365 ProPlus in your collection, you must use the Active Directory identities for your users.
trans-unit.target: If you are using Office 365 ProPlus in your collection, you must use the Active Directory identities for your users.

trans-unit.source: This helps validate licensing.
trans-unit.target: This helps validate licensing.

trans-unit.source: Once the users are validated, click Save.
trans-unit.target: Once the users are validated, click Save.

trans-unit.source: Next steps
trans-unit.target: Next steps

trans-unit.source: That's it - you have successfully created and deployed your RemoteApp hybrid collection.
trans-unit.target: That's it - you have successfully created and deployed your RemoteApp hybrid collection.

trans-unit.source: The next step is to have your users download and install the Remote Desktop client.
trans-unit.target: The next step is to have your users download and install the Remote Desktop client.

trans-unit.source: You can find the URL for the client on the RemoteApp Quick Start page.
trans-unit.target: You can find the URL for the client on the RemoteApp Quick Start page.

trans-unit.source: Then, have users log into the client and access the apps you published.
trans-unit.target: Then, have users log into the client and access the apps you published.
